questions.text: All of the following are the connective tissue layers of the skeletal muscle except ______
questions.solution:
Sarcolemma is the cell membrane of the muscle cell, while the remaining options are connective tissue layers surrounding the muscle.

A muscle is made up of individual muscle fibers. Each muscle fiber is a single cell that is multinucleated, long, cylindrical, and surrounded by a cell membrane, the sarcolemma.

Arrangement of the connective tissue is shown below.

questions.text: Which of the following is a regulatory muscle protein?
questions.solution:
Tropomyosin is a regulatory muscle protein.

It extends over the entire actin filament and covers the myosin-binding sites on the actin molecules thus preventing the attachment of actin to myosin.

One molecule covers 7 active sites on actin

 

Troponin is another regulatory protein. Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:

  • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
  • troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
  • troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca2+ that helps initiate contraction.

questions.text: Which of the following does not belong to dystrophin-glycoprotein complex?
questions.solution:
Perlecan is a large extracellular matrix proteoglycan that plays a crucial role in tissue development and organogenesis.

Dystrophin-glycoprotein complex

  • The dystrophin-glycoprotein complex provides a structural link between the cytoskeleton of the muscle cell and the extracellular matrix, which appears to stabilize the sarcolemma, adds strength to the muscle by providing a scaffolding for the fibrils and prevents contraction-induced injury (rupture).
  • Organisation of DG complex
    • Dystrophin connects F-actin to the transmembrane protein β-dystroglycan via smaller proteins called Syntrophins.  
    • This β-dystroglycan, in turn connects to the merosin subunit of laminin 211 in the extracellular matrix via α-dystroglycan. 
    • The dystroglycans are also associated with a complex of four transmembrane glycoproteins, α-, β-, γ-, and δ-sarcoglycan and sarcospan.

 

APPLIED ASPECT

  • Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy
    • X-linked recessive disorder
    • Deletion of DMD gene which codes for Dystrophin
  • Becker muscular Dystrophy
    • Dystrophin is present but altered or reduced in amount
  • Limb Girdle Dystrophy
    • Sarcoglycan is mutated

questions.text: Thin filaments consists of all of the following except _______
questions.solution:
Myosin forms the thick filament, while actin, troponin, and tropomyosin form the thin filament.

Thin Filaments in Sarcomere

  • The thin filaments are polymers made up of two chains of actin that form a long double helix.
  • Tropomyosin molecules are long filaments located in the groove between the two chains in the actin.
    • Each thin filament contains 300–400 actin molecules and 40–60 tropomyosin molecules.
  • Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along the tropomyosin molecules.
    • Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:
      • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
      • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
      • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca 2+ that helps to initiate contraction.

questions.text: Which of the following proteins is present in skeletal muscles, but absent in a smooth muscle?
questions.solution:
Actin, myosin, and tropomyosin are present in both skeletal muscle and smooth muscle. But troponin is absent and calmodulin is present in smooth muscle.

questions.text: Myosin filament has a fixed length of ______.
questions.solution: The total length of each myosin filament is uniform, almost exactly 1.6 micrometers.

questions.text:
The thick filament is made up of ________.
1. Heavy chain of myosin
2. Light chain of myosin
3. Dystrophin
4. Titin
questions.solution:
The thick filament or the myosin is made up of the heavy chain of myosin and light chain of myosin.

The myosin molecule is composed of six polypeptide chains- Two heavy chains, each with a molecular weight of about 200,000, and four light chains with molecular weights of about 20,000 each.

The two heavy chains wrap spirally around each other to form a double helix, which is called the tail of the myosin molecule.

One end of each of these chains is folded into a globular polypeptide structure called a myosin head. These heads contain an actin-binding site and a catalytic site that hydrolyzes ATP. Thus, there are two free heads at one end of the double-helix myosin molecule.

The four light chains are also part of the myosin head, two to each head. These light chains help control the function of the head during muscle contraction.

questions.text: Pseudo H zone in a sarcomere extends between the ______
questions.solution:
Pseudo H-zone is the light area between the two sides of M line due to reversal of polarity of the myosin molecules in each of the thick filaments.

Sarcomere

  • The sarcomere is the contractile unit of the skeletal muscle fibre.
    • Z line: provides attachment to actin filaments. The area between two adjacent Z lines is called the sarcomere.
    • It is composed of thick and thin filaments:
      • Thick filament : Myosin
      • Thin filaments : Actin, tropomyosin and troponin 
  • I band: 
    • Isotropic to light.
    • Only thin filaments. 
    • Half lies in one sarcomere and half in the next.
  • A band: 
    • Anisotropic to light.
    • Myosin plus overlapped actin.
  • H bands:
    • lighter area in the centre of A band, when the muscle is relaxed, the thin filaments do not overlap the thick filaments.
    • Only Myosin
  • Pseudo H: light portion on two sides of M line because of absence of cross bridges (no myosin head).
  • M line: centre of A band. Here there are slender cross-connections that hold the thick filaments in proper array.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: A cross-sectional view of a skeletal muscle fiber through the H zone would reveal the presence of  _______
questions.solution:
H zone is the central region of the A band which is lighter than the outer edges of the A band because the H zone is occupied by thick filaments only (No cross bridges)

In the figure, note the section through various levels and the myofilaments observed.

  • Section through I band → only actin (thin filament)
  • Section through A band (Exlcuding H zone) → Actin and Myosin
  • Section through H zone → only myosin (thick filament)
  • Section through M line → thick filament linked with accessory proteins
  • Section at AI junction → both actin and myosin

questions.text: The titin protein present in the muscle fiber binds ______

choices.text: The tail ends of actin filaments to Z disc
The head ends of myosin filaments to the Z disc
The tail ends of myosin filaments to M disc
The myofibrils to each other, and also to the cell membrane

questions.solution:
The titin protein present in the muscle fiber binds the head ends of myosin filaments to the Z disc

Several proteins other than actin and myosin are also present in the muscle. Some of them include:

1. Titin:

  • It is the largest known protein.
  • It runs between the M line and Z disc and binds the head ends of myosin filaments to the Z disc.
  • It has a tethered portion in the A band, where it is attached to the myosin filament and an elastic portion in the I band.
  • The elastic property of the titin causes elastic recoil of the sarcomere and prevents it from being overstretched.

2. Nebulin: 

  • It extends from the Z disc and runs along the full length of each actin filament.
  • It regulates the length of the actin filaments.

3. α-actinin: 

  • It is a component of the Z discs 
  • It binds the plus ends of actin filaments to this disc.

4. Myomesin

  • It is present in the region of the M line. 
  • It maintains the regular lattice arrangement of the myosin filaments in this region.

5. Desmin:

  • It is an intermediate filament characteristic of the muscle
  • It encircles the myofibrils near the Z disc and binds myofibrils to each other and also to the cell membrane.

6. Dystrophin:

  • It is present in the periphery of the muscle fiber, towards the cytoplasmic face of the sarcolemma.
  • It binds to the actin filaments and the glycoprotein complex, consisting of dystroglycan and sarcoglycan that spans the sarcolemma.

questions.text: Which of the following is the constituent of the marked area in the electron microscopic picture of muscle?
questions.solution:
Alpha actinin is the constituent of the marked area.

The image depicts sarcomere and the arrow points towards Z-line. Alpha actinin binds actin to Z-lines.

The orderly arrangement of actin, myosin, and related proteins that produces this pattern. The area between two Z-lines is called sarcomere.

The thick filaments, which are about twice the diameter of the thin filaments, are made up of myosin, which are lined to form A bands; the thin filaments are made up of actin, tropomyosin, and troponin. The array of thin filaments extends out of the A band and into the less dense staining I bands.

The lighter H bands in the center of the A bands are the regions where, when the muscle is relaxed, the thin filaments do not overlap the thick filaments.  The Z lines allow for anchoring of the thin filaments.

Actinin, titin and desmin are additional structural proteins.Titin connects Z-lines to the M line and provides the scaffolding to the sarcomere.  Desmin adds structure to Z-lines by connecting Z-line to plasma membrane.


Note: Some sources say that even titin is a component of Z-disc so if alpha actinin is not given in the options titin is the second best answer.

questions.text: Muscle myosin and actin filaments are kept in place by ______
questions.solution:
The side-by-side relationship between the myosin and actin filaments is maintained by a large number of filamentous molecules of a protein called titin.

Titin is a filamentous and springy protein. These springy titin molecules act as a framework that holds the myosin and actin filaments in place so that the contractile machinery of the sarcomere will work.

One end of the titin molecule is elastic and is attached to the Z disk, acting as a spring and changing length as the sarcomere contracts and relaxes. The other part of the titin molecule tethers it to the myosin thick filament.

APPLIED ASPECT

  • The mutation of genes encoding for titin has been associated with dilated and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

  • The skeletal muscle—associated tibialis muscular dystrophy is a genetic muscle disease of titin that is predicted to destabilize the folded state of the protein.

questions.text: Choose the true statement regarding the sarcomere in skeletal muscle.

choices.text: Desmin binds Z line to sarcoplasmic reticulum
Actinin binds  M line to actin
Titin binds M line to z line
The length of myosin changes with contraction

questions.solution:
Titin binds M line to Z line

Other options

Desmin binds Z line to sarcolemma ( not  sarcoplasmic reticulum)

Actinin binds  Z line to actin ( not M line; in fact, one of the two attachments of actin, desmin and titin, is always Z line)

Titin binds M line to z line, forms scaffolding, is responsible for muscle elasticity, is the largest known protein (Largest protein - titin; Largest gene - Dystrophin; Most abundant protein - Collagen )

The length of myosin or actin does not change with contraction; actually, the length of zones I and H  get changed (i.e, gets decreased )

Related Pearl: Sarcomere

questions.text: Which of the following occurs during skeletal muscle contraction?

choices.text: Both H and I band shorten
Both A and I band shorten
Both A and H band shorten

questions.solution:
Sliding of thin filament over thick filament (cross bridge formation) reduces the length of I and H band.

  • During contraction, the Z lines come closer to each other reducing the length of the sarcomere.
  • The A band remains constant and M line becomes prominent.

Related Pearl: Sarcomere

questions.text: The cross-bridges of the sarcomere in skeletal muscle are made up of _______.
questions.solution:
When the action potential reaches the muscle fiber, there is influx of Ca2+ ions. This  Ca2+ binds to troponin C and tropomyosin is moved out of the way. Myosin heads can now bind to actin and form so-called cross-bridges.

When a head attaches to an active site, this attachment simultaneously causes profound changes in the intramolecular forces between the head and arm of its cross-bridge. This causes the head to tilt toward the arm and to drag the actin filament along with it. This tilt of the head is called the power stroke. 

Immediately after tilting, the head then automatically breaks away from the active site.

Formation of cross-bridges is associated with hydrolysis of ATP and generation of force.

questions.text: ATPase activity is present in ______.
questions.solution:
A feature of the myosin head that is essential for muscle contraction is that it functions as an adenosine triphosphatase (ATPase) enzyme.

Chemical Events during Muscle Contraction

  • Before contraction begins, the heads of the cross-bridges bind with ATP. The ATPase activity of the myosin head immediately cleaves the ATP but leaves the cleavage products, ADP plus phosphate ion, bound to the head. (Point A)
  • When the troponin-tropomyosin complex binds with calcium ions, active sites on the actin filament are uncovered and the myosin heads then bind with these sites. (Point B)
  • The bond between the head of the cross-bridge and the active site of the actin filament causes a conformational change in the head and the power stroke occurs. (Point C)
  • Once the head of the cross-bridge tilts, the ADP and phosphate ion that were previously attached to the head are released and a new ATP moelcule binds in that place. (Point D)
  • The binding of the new ATP molecule causes detachment of the head of myosin from the actin. (Point D)
  • This cycle is then repeated.

questions.text: Myosin head detaches from actin by which of the following mechanism?

choices.text: Entry of calcium into sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.solution: Binding of ATP on the free site of myosin leads to the detachment of myosin head from the thin filament.

questions.text: In human skeletal muscles, calcium ions are stored in?
questions.solution:
In a skeletal muscle, calcium ions are majorly stored in the terminal cisterns of the Sarcoplasmic Reticulum.

Terminal cisterns are the lateral sacs of the sarcoplasmic reticulum. The spread of action potential triggers the release of Ca2+ from the terminal cisterns.

The sarcolemma is the cell membrane of the skeletal muscle. Transverse tubules are the internal extensions of the sarcolemma.

questions.text: All of the following are true about excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle except that _____

choices.text: Acetylcholine is released at the nerve terminal.
Ca2+ is released from sarcoplasmic reticulum during contraction.
Ca2+ is pumped back into sarcoplasmic reticulum during relaxation.
Ca2+ binds to tropomyosin to initiate muscle contraction.

questions.solution: Ca2+ binds to troponin C (not tropomyosin) to initiate muscle contraction.

questions.text: A skeletal muscle contraction ends when _______.

choices.text: Ions move out of the cytoplasm
Ach is metabolised at the Neuromusclular junction (NMR)
Decreased calcium outside the sarcoplasmic reticulum

questions.solution:
Once the Ca2+ concentration outside the sarcoplasmic reticulum has been lowered sufficiently, chemical interaction between myosin and actin ceases and the muscle relaxes.

  • The SERCA pump uses energy from ATP hydrolysis to remove Ca2+ from the cytosol back into the terminal cisterns, where it is stored until released by the next action potential.
  • Thus during relaxation
    • Ca2+ concentration in cytoplasmic decreases.
    • Ca2+ concentration in sarcoplasmic reticulum increases.

Option a: Calcium ions do not move out of the cytoplasm. They are taken up by the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

questions.text: A bodybuilder is regularly working out in a gym. Which of the following is true regarding total heat production during muscle contraction?

choices.text: Activation heat is produced when a muscle is contracting
Initial heat produced is due to the basal metabolic processes.
Relaxation heat is present in both isotonic and isometric contractions
Recovery heat of muscle is greater than the initial heat

questions.solution:
Activation heat is the heat that muscle produces whenever it contracts.

Heat Production in Muscle

  • Resting heat: The heat given off at rest due to the basal metabolic processes.
  • Initial heat: The heat produced in excess of resting heat during contraction. It is made up two subtypes:
    • Activation heat: The heat that muscle produces whenever it is contracting, and
    • Shortening heat: The heat which is proportional in amount to the distance the muscle shortens. Shortening heat is apparently due to some change in the structure of the muscle during shortening.
  • Recovery heat:  this is  the heat liberated by the metabolic processes that restore the muscle to its precontraction state. The recovery heat of muscle is approximately equal to the initial heat.
  • Relaxation heat: Heat released in a muscle that has contracted isotonically to restore it to its previous length. This extra heat is in addition to recovery heat.

questions.text: In a 100-m dash, most of the energy consumed by skeletal muscles to replenish ATP is derived from _______
questions.solution:
In a 100-m dash that takes 10 s, 85% of the energy consumed is derived anaerobically by phosphocreatine, which is hydrolyzed to creatine and phosphate groups with the release of considerable energy.

The ATP concentration in a muscle is low enough (4 millimolar) to sustain contractions for 1-2 seconds after which ATP is dephosphorylated into ADP. The ADP is re-phosphorylated by phosphocreatine for the next 5 to 8 seconds.

ADP is re-phosphorylated by 3 sources.
  • Phosphocreatine after 2 seconds upto 10 seconds.
  • Glycolysis (anaerobic) after 10 seconds upto a minute
  • Oxidative metabolism - after a minute upto 2-4 hours.

questions.text: The length of the muscle fiber at the onset of contraction which is required to attain the maximum active tension is known as
questions.solution:
The length of the muscle fiber at the onset of contraction which is required to attain maximum active tension is known as resting length.

Resting length is also known as the optimum length. It is about 2μm. At this length, there is a maximal overlap between the actin and myosin fibers and therefore, the maximum number of cross-bridge binding sites are formed.

Passive tension is the tension in a muscle when it is not stimulated. Total tension is the tension developed when a muscle contracts isometrically in response to a maximal stimulus.

Active tension = Total tension - Passive tension

When the muscle fiber contracts, the active tension developed is proportional to the number of cross-bridges between the actin and myosin fibers. Hence, at the resting length, maximum active tension is produced and the muscle fiber contracts with a maximum force of contraction.

In the given image, the purple line represents the passive tension in the muscle (before contraction) and its relation with the muscle length, while the red line represents the total tension present (during contraction) and its relation with the muscle length.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the resting length of a muscle fiber except ________.

choices.text: There are maximum cross-bridges between actin and myosin
The resting length is around 2μm in humans
The velocity of contraction is maximum for any given load

questions.solution:
The passive tension is not maximum at resting length of a muscle fiber.

Passive tension is the tension in a muscle when it is not stimulated. Total tension is the tension developed when a muscle contracts isometrically in response to a maximal stimulus.

Active tension = Total tension - Passive tension

The active tension is maximum at the resting length of a muscle fiber. This is because there is a optimal overlap between the actin and myosin fibers at the resting length and therefore the maximum number of cross-bridges are formed. (Option A) This provides for the maximum force of contraction at this length. The active tension decreases as the muscle is stretched beyond its normal length. The resting length is around 2μm in humans. (Option C)

The velocity of muscle contraction varies inversely with the load on the muscle i.e. as the load on the muscle increases, the velocity of contraction decreases. At a given load, the velocity is maximal at the resting length and declines if the muscle is shorter or longer than this length. (Option D)

questions.text: Active tension in a muscle depends upon which of the following?
questions.solution:
Active tension in a muscle depends upon the number of motor units recruited.

The greater the number of motor units recruited, the greater will be the active tension.

Factors affecting muscle tension

 

Tension developed by each fiber

  • Action potential frequency
  • Fiber length (length-tension relationship)
  • Fiber diameter
  • Fatigue

Number of active fibers

  • Number of fibers per motor unit
  • Number of active motor units (recruitment)

questions.text: Which of the following have the maximum density of white muscle fibers?
questions.solution:
Extra-ocular muscles have the maximum density of white muscle fibers (type IIB), which contract quickly with peak tension attained within 7.5 msec of stimulation.

questions.text: A motor unit is made up of _______________.

choices.text: All the muscle fibers within a given muscle
A motor neuron and the muscle fibers it innervates
All the neurons going into an muscle of the body

questions.solution:
Each single motor neuron and the muscle fibers it innervates constitute a motor unit.

  • The number of muscle fibers in a motor unit varies.
    • In muscles concerned with fine, graded, precise movement, (eg. extraoccular muscles) each motor unit innervates very few (three to six) muscle fibers.
    • On the other hand, in human leg and back muscles, number of muscle fibers per motor unit can be upto 600. 
  • Each spinal motor neuron innervates only one kind of muscle fiber, so that all the muscle fibers in a motor unit are of the same type.
  • On the basis of the type of muscle fiber they innervate, and thus on the basis of the duration of their twitch contraction, motor units are divided into S (slow), FR (fast, resistant to fatigue), and FF (fast, fatigable) units.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the recruitment of fast fatiguable motor unit ?
questions.solution:
The fast fatigable motor unit is recruited last.

Each single motor neuron and the muscle fibers it innervates constitute a motor unit. On the basis of the type of muscle fiber they innervate, and thus on the basis of the duration of their twitch contraction, motor units are divided into

  •   S (slow)
  •   FR (fast, resistant to fatigue)
  •   FF (fast, fatigable) units.

S fibers have a low innervation ratio (ie, small units) and FF fibers have a high innervation ratio (i.e., large units).

The recruitment of motor units during muscle contrac­tion follows a general scheme, the size principle.

  • In general, a specific muscle action is developed first by the recruitment of S muscle units that contract relatively slowly to produce controlled contraction.
  • Next, FR muscle units are recruited, resulting in more powerful response over a shorter period of time.
  • Lastly, FF muscle units are recruited for the most demanding tasks.

questions.text: A scientist found that the latent period of muscle twitch is 10 ms and the contraction period is 40 ms. What is the tetanizing frequency (Hz)?
questions.solution:
Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1/40 ms = 25 Hz.

Tetanizing frequency

  • As the contractile mechanism does not have a refractory period, on rapid stimulation of a muscle, each new contraction occurs before the preceding one is over. As a result, the second contraction is added partially to the first, and thus the total strength of contraction rises progressively with increasing frequency. Such a response is called a tetanus (tetanic contraction). It is a complete tetanus when no relaxation occurs between stimuli.
  • Tetany occurs because enough calcium ions are maintained in the muscle sarcoplasm throughout the period of stimulation.

Muscle physiology and associated pathologies are frequently tested on multiple exams.

questions.text: Tetanic contraction is due to the accumulation of _______ ions.
questions.solution:
Tetanic contraction occurs due to progressive accumulation of Ca2+ ions with rapidly repeated stimulation of skeletal muscle.

  • With rapidly repeated stimulation, activation of the contractile mechanism occurs repeatedly before any relaxation has occurred, and the individual contractions fuse into one continuous contraction. Such a response is called a tetanus (tetanic contraction).
  • A single action potential releases sufficient Ca2+ to cause a twitch contraction.
  • However, the duration of this contraction is very short because Ca2+ is very rapidly pumped back into the SR.
  • If the muscle is stimulated a second time before the muscle is fully relaxed, there is progressive accumulation of Ca2+ and the force of contraction increases. Thus, twitch forces are amplified as stimulus frequency increases.
  • At a high level of stimulation, intracellular Ca2+ increases and is maintained throughout the period of stimulation, and the amount of force developed greatly exceeds that seen during a twitch. The response is termed tetany.

questions.text: The function of the Golgi tendon organ is to _________

choices.text: Sense changes in position of the muscle
Sense changes in length of the muscle

questions.solution:
Golgi tendon organ sense changes in muscle tension.

Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex) is disynaptic, is the opposite of the stretch reflex.

When the tension in a contracted muscle is significantly elevated, the inhibitory effect from the Golgi tendon organ leads to instantaneous relaxation of the entire muscle. This effect is called the lengthening reaction.

It is a protective mechanism to prevent tearing of the muscle or avulsion of the tendon from its attachments to the bone.

Note: Muscle spindles senses changes in muscle length (stretch).

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding mechanisms of depolarisation, repolarisation, and hyperpolarisation in a skeletal muscle action potential?
  1. Depolarisation due to influx of Na+ through voltage-gated channels
  2. Depolarisation due to influx of Na+ through ligand-gated channels
  3. Repolarisation due to efflux of K+ through a voltage-gated channel
  4. Repolarisation due to efflux of K+ through a ligand-gated channel
  5. Hyperpolarisation due to efflux of K+
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 3, and 5 are correct.

Action potential in skeletal muscle:

  • Motor-neuron discharge causes end-plate potential, which when reaches to a threshold value, causes action potential in the muscle fibre.
  • The depolarization of the muscle fibre is caused by the activation of the voltage-gated sodium channels, which causes the influx of sodium.
  • During repolarization, the sodium channels are closed, and voltage-gated potassium channels open, which causes efflux of potassium.
  • The voltage-gated potassium channels close slowly. As a result, the potassium efflux continues, leading to hyperpolarization of the membrane.

The steps in an action potential in muscle fibre and the neuron, are similar except for the quantitative differences, such as:

  • RMP is -80 to -90 mV in skeletal muscle fibres, while it is about -70mV in neurons.
  • The duration of the action potential in skeletal muscle is 1 to 5 msec, which is about 5 times longer than in the largest myelinated nerve fibre.
  • The velocity of conduction is about 3-5m/s, which is about 1/13th of the velocity of the nerve fibre.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about skeletal muscle contraction?
  1. Extracellular Ca2+ is not important for contraction
  2. Ca2+ is released from mitochondria
  3. Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
  4. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on sarcolemma have no role in EC coupling
questions.solution:
During the contraction of the skeletal muscle, the Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Only statement 3 is correct.

Excitation contraction coupling refers to the process by which the membrane depolarization of the muscle fibre (excitation) leads to the contraction of the muscle.

The steps of excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle are as follows:

  • Motor-neuron discharge causes the release of acetylcholine at the motor endplate, which binds to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.
  • This causes increased Na+ and K+ conductance in the endplate membrane, leading to the generation of end-plate potential, which is a local potential.
  • When the local endplate potential reaches a threshold for the muscle fibre, and an action potential is generated.
  • The generated action potential passes inward through the T tubules, leading to the spread of depolarisation.
  • The depolarization of the muscle fibre causes the release of Ca2+ from terminal cisterns of sarcoplasmic reticulum and diffusion to thick and thin filaments.
  • The calcium released, binds to troponin C, uncovering myosin-binding sites on actin.
  • The formation of cross-linkages between actin and myosin and sliding of thin on thick filaments causes contraction of the skeletal muscle.

Steps in relaxation:

  • The cytoplasmic calcium is pumped back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, by the action of SERCA (sarcoplasmic endoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase).
  • Once the calcium concentration is lowered, the interaction between actin and myosin ceases, and the muscle relaxes. 
 
Other options:
 
Statement 1: Incorrect - Extracellular calcium levels play an important role in muscle contraction. When there is a decrease in extracellular calcium as in hypocalcemia, the voltage-gated sodium channels are activated, which causes sodium influx. The increased intracellular sodium concentration causes sustained depolarization, which may lead to tetany.
 
Statement 2: Incorrect - Ca2+ is not released from mitochondria. It is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
 
Statement 4: Voltage-gated calcium channels on T-tubules (part of sarcolemma) are activated by a depolarizing stimulus, which causes the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. The increased calcium concentration will eventually lead to muscle contraction.
